title: (Schools) GDPR Part 2: Data handling rules
body:
Welcome to this course on data handling rules.

This is the second part in the GDPR suite.

To help you as you go through the module, a glossary of terms is available, by clicking on the icon in the top right hand corner.

This course should take approximately 20-25 minutes to complete. 

Click or tap on one of the sections below to begin.

_glossaryItems.description: Accountability refers to taking responsibility for actions, tasks or processes. In the case of GDPR, accountability refers to the various obligations that organisations will have to follow in order to demonstrate data protection compliance.

The Article 29 Working Party (Art. 29 WP) is made up of a representative from the data protection authority of each EU Member State, the European Data Protection Supervisor and the European Commission.
Where the relevant supervisory authority is notified of a data breach.
The data controller says how and why personal data is processed.
Data collected and processed should not be retained or further used unless this is necessary for purposes that were clearly stated in advance.
The ability to obtain and reuse personal data.
Any operation performed on personal data, whether by automated means or otherwise, including collection, use, recording, etc.
The data processor acts on the controllerâ€™s behalf and is required to maintain records of personal data and processing activities.
An exemption from, or relaxation of, a rule or law.
The removal of writing, recorded material or data. In this case, the removal of data.

The ICO is a non-departmental public body whose mission it is to "uphold information rights in the public interest, promoting openness by public bodies and data privacy for individuals". The ICO reports directly to Parliament and is sponsored by the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport.
This involves organisations releasing data that they hold about customers back to them in a portable electronic format.

A breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed in connection with the provision of a public electronic communications service,
The Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR) sit alongside the Data Protection Act. They give people specific privacy rights in relation to electronic communications.
_glossaryItems.term: Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2011 (PECR)

_glossaryItems.description: An approach that promotes privacy and data protection compliance from the beginning.
Procedure where data fields are replaced by one or more artificial identifiers, or pseudonyms.
The act of correcting something or putting it right, in this case, the rectification of personal data
Details regarding the purpose, use and processing of personal data and who it will be shared with.
A person or business that sells goods or services.

A board of management of which nonmanagerial workers are members, having supervisory powers over some aspects of management decision-making. It is usually a governing body that dictates the terms of processes.
Information about transactions, for example in banking. Any information about banking transactions will be referred to as transactional data.
Full disclosure on how data is used.
